author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Oregon and other states link reopening measures to vaccine targets.
description: While some states are offering residents incentives like savings bonds or sports tickets to encourage them to be vaccinated, a few are making a very different pitch: The sooner you get a shot, the sooner the state will fully reopen.
content: While some states are offering residents incentives like savings bonds or sports tickets to encourage them to be vaccinated, a few are making a very different pitch: The sooner you get a shot, the sooner the state will fully reopen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Nicholas Fandos
title: Amid Economic Turmoil, Biden Stays Focused on Longer Term
description: The president’s advisers are pushing their most detailed argument yet for the long-term benefits of a $4 trillion agenda to remake the American economy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his economic team on Thursday made their most detailed case yet for trillions of dollars in new federal spending to rebuild public investment in workers, research and physical infrastructure, focusing on long-term ingredients of economic growth and equality as the current recovery from recession showed signs of distress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The C.D.C. said vaccinated Americans may stop wearing masks in most indoor and outdoor settings.
content: The masks are coming off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: A new Starz comedy follows four 30-something friends in Harlem, and a new Netflix series stars Ewan McGregor as the fashion designer Halston. Who’s feeling fabulous?
content: Every Monday and Friday, we offer hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: What Voters in Wyoming Say About Liz Cheney’s Lonely Stand
description: In a heavily Republican state, their lone congresswoman’s defiance of the former president is unpopular. But some residents still stick up for her. “She told the truth!” one proclaimed.
content: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — On a prairie hill on the rolling highway into Wyoming’s capital city looms a billboard with the beaming face of the state’s lone congressional representative, Liz Cheney. In huge letters it declares: “Thank you Rep. Cheney for defending the Constitution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Colonial Pipeline reports ‘substantial progress’ in restoring the flow of fuel.
description: Gasoline prices continue to rise in the Southeast, and a complete return to normal supplies will take days.
content: Gasoline prices continued to rise across the Southeast on Thursday, but at a slower pace generally than in recent days, as the operator of Colonial Pipeline said it had made “substantial progress” in resuming the delivery of fuel along the East Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Plans to Reduce Jobless Benefits Spreads to 16 States
description: The moves, scheduled for June and July, will affect roughly two million people.
content: With new claims for unemployment benefits inching down, a growing number of Republican governors around the country have announced that they are withdrawing from an array of federal pandemic-related jobless benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Emily Cochrane
title: The White House is said to be quietly pushing for a change to the D.C. statehood bill.
description: The Biden administration has quietly approached congressional Democrats about a potential change to their high-profile but long-shot effort to transform most of the District of Columbia into the nation’s 51st state, according to executive and legislative branch officials.
content: The Biden administration has quietly approached congressional Democrats about a potential change to their high-profile but long-shot effort to transform most of the District of Columbia into the nation’s 51st state, according to executive and legislative branch officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iyad Abuheweila
title: In Gaza, cheers turned into desperation and fear.
description: GAZA CITY — On Tuesday evening, Gazans celebrated as they heard the whoosh of rockets sent toward Israel.
content: GAZA CITY — On Tuesday evening, Gazans celebrated as they heard the whoosh of rockets sent toward Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Adam Nagourney
title: How Will California’s Arts Institutions Recover?
description: Thursday: A conversation about major cultural institutions and philanthropy in the aftermath of the pandemic.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: While supervising new digital restorations of several of his films, the Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai made certain adjustments, such as changing the aspect ratio — the image dimensions — of “Fallen Angels,” which now has a wider frame than it did when it was first shown in 1995.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Even if You Think Discussing Aliens Is Ridiculous, Just Hear Me Out
description: How would contact with U.F.O.s and other civilizations change ours?
content: The most curious subplot in the news right now is the admission, at the most senior levels of the United States government, that the military services have collected visuals, data and testimonials recording flying objects they cannot explain; that they are investigating these phenomena seriously; and that they will, in the coming months, report at least some of their findings to the public. It feels, at times, like the beginning of a film where everyone is going about their lives, even as the earthshaking events unfurl on a silenced television in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: To Understand Amazon, We Must Understand Jeff Bezos
description: In “Amazon Unbound,” his second book about the company, Brad Stone focuses on its singular C.E.O.
content: AMAZON UNBOUNDJeff Bezos and the Invention of a Global EmpireBy Brad Stone
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Mark Mazzetti
title: Activists and Ex-Spy Said to Have Plotted to Discredit Trump ‘Enemies’ in Government
description: The campaign included planned operations against President Trump’s national security adviser at the time, H.R. McMaster, and F.B.I. employees, according to documents and interviews.
content: WASHINGTON — A network of conservative activists, aided by a British former spy, mounted a campaign during the Trump administration to discredit perceived enemies of President Trump inside the government, according to documents and people involved in the operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: In Mixed Israel Cities Proud of Good Relations, a Sudden, Explosive Division
description: Not even during the intifadas, the mass Palestinian uprisings of the past, did Israel experience such a surge of both Arab and Jewish mob violence.
content: LOD, Israel — The Arabs and Jews of Lod, one of the most closely mixed cities in Israel, have been through many upheavals. But they had never before seen the kind of inter-community violence that unfolded here over the past three days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: How Real Estate Blew Up in the Hamptons and Greenwich
description: Both are wealthy areas, but they’re different markets. So what’s driving the parallel booms?
content: Real estate is booming almost everywhere amid the pandemic, but the gains in local housing markets are far from equal. Two wealthy New York City satellites, the Hamptons and Greenwich, Conn., are quickly outpacing their neighbors in sales volume — a development that isn’t as predictable as you might think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: New York Is Reawakening. It Just Needs Its Tourists Back.
description: After a year of staying away, visitors are trickling back. Now, city officials and business leaders are plotting ways to lure them in large numbers.
content: For 10 straight years leading up to the coronavirus pandemic, a torrent of tourists from around the world poured into New York City, with their numbers rising to a record level in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Roni Caryn Rabin, Apoorva Mandavilli and Noah Weiland
title: Some states lift mask mandates for vaccinated people, while others greet the new C.D.C. guidance with caution.
description: The new policy seemed to catch many retailers and their workers by surprise, and a major union for food workers asked whether they were supposed to serve as “vaccination police.”
content: As federal health officials on Thursday cleared the way for Americans who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to drop mask wearing in most situations, some states lifted mask mandates, while others took a more cautious approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: President of Key Teachers’ Union Shares Plea: ‘Schools Must Be Open’ in Fall
description: About half the nation’s schools are not fully open despite rising vaccination levels, and teachers’ unions are getting much of the blame. Randi Weingarten hopes to carve a path forward.
content: Randi Weingarten, president of the nation’s second-largest teachers’ union, called on Thursday for a full reopening of the nation’s schools for the next academic year, saying: “There is no doubt: Schools must be open. In person. Five days a week.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Profile’ Review: Screen Sharing With Extremists
description: Interactions between a journalist and a recruiter for the Islamic State play out over screens in this hackneyed thriller.
content: The shallow thriller “Profile” tells the story of Amy (Valene Kane), an ambitious British journalist on a mission to expose an Islamic State recruitment ring that targets European women. She creates a false identity with a Facebook profile to match, and draws the attention of Bilel (Shazad Latif), a London-born recruiter. Undercover, Amy begins to flirt with Bilel, suggesting her readiness to travel to Syria. Her investigation is dangerous, but the risk plays out entirely online. It’s provocative material, but unfortunately “Profile” is more interested in gimmicks than analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Artists in a Post-George Floyd, Mid-Pandemic World
description: Two new exhibitions at Mass MoCA created over the past year offer insights into our new normal.
content: Two shows that recently opened at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art are keyed to our new normal: One came into being during the most restrictive moments of the pandemic; the other, though long planned, shifted its focus as these past, momentous months unfolded. Conceptually, both address the questions — personal and political — that are on many minds at the moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Eugene Webb, Leading Harlem Real Estate Broker, Dies at 102
description: Raised in Alabama, he made his fortune in New York and became a banker, civic leader and developer.
content: Eugene H. Webb, who was raised in racially segregated Alabama with modest ambitions, but who after transplanting himself to Harlem established what became the nation’s largest Black-owned real estate management company, died on April 5 at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Coronavirus Vaccines Protect Pregnant Women, Another Study Suggests
description: The shots may also have benefits for infants and do not seem to damage the placenta, according to the latest research.
content: When the coronavirus vaccines were first authorized in December, scientists knew little about how well they might work in pregnant women, who had been excluded from the clinical trials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: From David Hammons, a Tribute to Pier 52 and Lastingness
description: Their artistic paths crossed like ships in the night. But in  “Day’s End,” Hammons creates an immortalizing homage to Gordon Matta-Clark and art history.
content: In 2014, the director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, Adam D. Weinberg, invited the artist David Hammons to tour the museum’s still empty new building. Weinberg remembers them standing together at the panoramic fifth-floor window overlooking the Hudson and talking about the history of the waterfront facing the museum, about what was there and what was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Can My Daughter Play With Unmasked Children?
description: A reader asks for advice on dealing with neighbors who don’t enforce mask-wearing with their kids.
content: My wife and I have a disaster on our hands! We recently moved across the country with our 8-year-old daughter for a major job opportunity for my wife. We don’t know a soul in our suburban town. And I believe this is a critical time for our daughter to learn social skills and make friends (especially after a year of isolation). The problem: The only other kids in our neighborhood don’t mask or social distance when they ask her to play. When I talked to their parents about Covid precautions, they looked at me like I had three heads and refused. Nothing is more important than our daughter’s safety, but we care about her socialization too. What should we do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: 58 Strikeouts Without a Walk. Then Ball Four.
description: Two years ago, Corbin Burnes had an 8.82 E.R.A. On Thursday he came off the Covid-19 injured list and set two major league strikeout records.
content: Twenty-six times this season, Corbin Burnes had stood on the mound with a chance to throw ball four. Every time, he had thrown a strike. It wasn’t until the 127th batter he faced that Burnes issued a walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Liz Cheney Matters
description: Her ouster is a sign of the Republican Party’s growing discomfort with democracy.
content: The Republican Party’s big recent moves — the ouster of Liz Cheney from a leadership position and the passage of new state voting laws — do not have much immediate impact on Americans’ lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Train Workers’ Covid Bonus Offer Turns Out to Be a Phishing Test
description: As pandemic-related scams rise, experts say companies should tread carefully with cybersecurity exercises like one that has prompted anger in Britain.
content: LONDON — The email from the payroll department of a British railroad company seemed to echo a refrain from many corporate offices during a difficult year, offering employees a link to a “one-off payment” to thank them for working under the strain of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Florida Governor Says He Will Pardon Those Who Violated Mask Mandates
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, said the enforcement of a county mask mandate was “total overreach.”
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said on Wednesday that he would pardon “any Floridian” who violated mask or social distancing mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcelle Hopkins
title: Lasers, a Drone and 31 Mics: How We Created a 3-D Experience of Hearing a Choir
description: What does a socially distant gospel choir sound like? Here’s how Times journalists and technologists put users inside the sanctuary of a church in Harlem.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What Do Used Car Prices Say About Biden’s Agenda?
description: What did we learn from April's inflation report? Not much.
content: So, should President Biden scrap his economic agenda because Americans are rushing to buy used cars?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Instagram blocked posts about the Aqsa Mosque in a terrorism screening error.
description: The social media network said it had mistakenly associated hashtags linked to the Jerusalem site with a terrorist organization.
content: Instagram removed some posts and restricted access to other content that used hashtags related to the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem after mistakenly associating the name with a terrorist organization, according to an internal company message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Reimagining the Justice System, From Inside the Mayor’s Office
description: Eric Cumberbatch has been on a mission to curb violence through community outreach.
content: Over the past year, civil rights protests have put American cities under pressure to rethink public safety. Even though calls to “defund the police” have lost some political momentum in New York, part of what the movement pushed for — investing in social services as a way to curb violence — has been a priority in the city for years. Much of that is overseen by Eric Cumberbatch, a deputy director in the Mayor’s Office of Criminal Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Mike Ives
title: Should We Stash Our Masks for Cold and Flu Season?
description: Wearing a mask when you’re sick is common in East Asia, but there’s no tidy scientific consensus on how much it limits the spread of respiratory illnesses.
content: Once Americans return to crowded offices, schools, buses and trains, so too will their sneezes and sniffles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chandler Burr
title: 52 Fragrances and How to Think About Them
description: An encyclopedia of some of the most interesting floral, woody, fresh and spicy scents around.
content: How do you organize perfume?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Enfant Terrible’ Review: I Can Sleep When I’m Dead
description: The packed biographical film “Enfant Terrible” races to keep up with the blazing life of the filmmaker Rainer Werner Fassbinder.
content: Oskar Roehler’s “Enfant Terrible” runs through an impressively packed compendium of Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s life and works — the brilliance, the sadism, the compassion and the leopard-print suiting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Tesla’s U-turn on Bitcoin raises questions of the cryptocurrency’s stability.
description: Elon Musk said Tesla would stop accepting Bitcoin as payment for cars, citing environmental reasons, a move that sent the price of the cryptocurrency plunging.
content: Elon Musk has been a big cryptocurrency booster of late, even directing Tesla to buy $1.5 billion in Bitcoin for its corporate treasury earlier this year. On Thursday, he abruptly reversed course, tweeting that Tesla would stop accepting Bitcoin as payment for cars, citing environmental reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Republicans Rewrite History of the Capitol Riot, Hampering an Inquiry
description: Republicans in Congress are insisting that any investigation into the Jan. 6 attack include an examination of left-wing violence.
content: WASHINGTON — Four months after supporters of President Donald J. Trump stormed the Capitol in a deadly riot, a growing number of Republicans in Congress are mounting a wholesale effort to rewrite the history of what happened on Jan. 6, downplaying or outright denying the violence and deflecting efforts to investigate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Killing of Two Lovers’ Review: What Lies Beneath
description: Under the veneer of an unusual marriage is an uncontrollable undercurrent to which everyone is susceptible.
content: Robert Machoian’s “The Killing of Two Lovers” opens like a crime thriller: A frantic man looms over his sleeping wife and her lover with a gun. Spooked by a noise, he runs off, and the camera follows him down an empty road in the Utah town where he lives with his ailing father. But a ticking time bomb of violence looms over this drama of a marriage, marked by his abjection and told in unpredictable long takes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Besonen
title: ‘I Should Have Known Better’: Travel Planning in Uncertain Times
description: We are navigating a new world of travel where planning for the unpredictable, more than ever, is part of the itinerary.
content: Tammy Barbie’s first family trip since the onset of the pandemic began with a strategic error.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Is He the Next Martha Stewart? ‘Not So Fast,’ Says Martha.
description: With a new book about a year at his stylish upstate farm, the ceramist Christopher Spitzmiller tries on the mantle of the lifestyle pundit.
content: Joan Rivers was honking her head off. Pat Altschul was pecking at grubs. Carolyne Roehm sat in a brooding shed, downy feathers fluffed about her, hatching an egg. Any time a visitor strayed near this small flock of Sebastopol geese, Bill Blass, the resident gander, stuck his neck out and hissed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘High Ground’ Review: Two Worlds Collide in the Outback
description: Directed by Stephen Johnson, this western set in Australia doesn’t follow the expected narrative.
content: This outback western, set in Australia’s Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory, begins in 1919, depicting a brutal massacre of a group of Indigenous people known as Yolngu. Above the killing fray is a rifleman named Travis (Simon Baker), a member of the party of white people encroaching on the land. The group below has gone against the mission — Travis was supposed to be the only member of the party authorized to shoot — so he descends from his defensive position and tries to save the Yolngu. One surviving Indigenous witness is a young boy named Gutjuk (Jacob Junior Nayinggul).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Finds Irony in the G.O.P. Vote to Cancel Liz Cheney
description: “I’m confused — I thought these guys hated cancel culture,” Kimmel said after the Republicans ousted Cheney from her leadership position in the House on Wednesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Finding You’ Review: A Fiddler Falls in Love
description: In this dull young adult romance, a violinist spends a semester abroad in Ireland and meets a famous dreamboat.
content: The cinematic teen girls in everything from “The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants” to “The Fault in Our Stars” go abroad to find themselves, but usually run into boy problems instead. “Finding You,” another phony girlish fantasy adapted from a popular young adult novel (“There You’ll Find Me” by Jenny B. Jones), is no different. But unlike the aforementioned titles, it lacks the personality and dramatic stakes to interest adult viewers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: National Gallery of Art Reopens With a New Vision: ‘For All the People’
description: The museum has a new logo and mantra as its director, Kaywin Feldman, moves to diversify the collection and the staff.
content: When the doors reopen at the National Gallery of Art on Friday, visitors may be surprised by new changes to this Washington museum’s look. Some 20 clashing typefaces and confusing signage have been gradually disappearing from the building, replaced by a new logo visible inside and out, and a new mantra — “Of the nation and for all the people”— that will appear on its website and be shared with staff. The museum says this vision statement, developed through meetings with employees, symbolizes a renewed commitment to diversity, inclusion and excellence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Rockfield: The Studio on the Farm’ Review: Rockers Ripping It Up
description: A documentary explores the Welsh farm-turned-studio, Rockfield, where Black Sabbath, the Stone Roses and others made music.
content: Rockers endeavoring to “get their heads together in the country” has been one of the great clichés of popular music since the late-1960s. As “Rockfield: The Studio on the Farm,” an agreeable new documentary directed by Hannah Berryman, amply testifies, “the country” was just as likely a place for rockers to lose their heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Adair and Colena Sesanker
title: Should Two- and Four-Year Degrees Be Free?
description: Reviving higher education in America requires a holistic solution that ends student debt and restores  dignity to educators.
content: The last 40 years have seen an ever-widening income gap between those with college degrees and those without. Over that interval, incomes have soared for those with advanced degrees and declined for those with high-school diplomas or less. As a result, the route to economic security for young people depends increasingly on access to higher education. Yet it keeps getting more expensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Books to Inspire Hunger and Thirst
description: Wine textbooks are crucial, but they may only rarely move you. What about books that teach you not only how to think about wine but how to feel about it?
content: It’s a tossup over whether my overstuffed apartment holds more wine or more books. The number of bottles tumbled about, particularly over the pandemic year, is rivaled only by the scattered stacks of volumes that sadly will never earn shelf space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘The Underground Railroad’ Weaves an Epic Vision
description: In Barry Jenkins’s dreamlike adaptation of the Colson Whitehead novel, the railway is real and so is the pain.
content: In Barry Jenkins’s transfixing adaptation of Colson Whitehead’s “The Underground Railroad,” Martin (Damon Herriman), a white man smuggling Cora (Thuso Mbedu) as she escapes slavery, rouses her before dawn to witness something ghastly. Along the road they’re traveling, grimly called “The Freedom Trail,” the trees are hung with lynched corpses. “You need to see this,” he tells her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees’ Virus Case Count Rises to Seven
description: The team announced that three coaches and four support staff members had tested positive as breakthrough cases ahead of Wednesday’s win over Tampa Bay.
content: The Yankees’ coronavirus outbreak increased to seven confirmed cases on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Inappropriate Behavior Cited in Resignation of Santa Clara U. President
description: The Rev. Kevin O’Brien had delivered the homily at a Mass for the inauguration of President Biden in January.
content: A Jesuit priest who delivered the homily at a Mass for the inauguration of President Biden has resigned as the president of Santa Clara University after he engaged in inappropriate behavior, university officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Azi Paybarah and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: N.Y.P.D. Officer Is Shot While Responding to Gunfire
description: The officer was expected to recover, and a suspect was in custody. The confrontation came after an earlier shooting in which a man was killed.
content: A New York City police officer was hospitalized after being shot three times in Brooklyn late Wednesday as he responded to an alert from a high-tech system that detects gunfire, the authorities said. A male suspect was also shot and apprehended at the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roy Furchgott
title: Crackdown on Emissions ‘Defeat Devices’ Has Amateur Racers Up in Arms
description: A recent court decision against a maker of aftermarket parts, coupled with the new possibility of criminal charges, has jolted an industry.
content: You might think Volkswagen’s $14.7 billion dirty diesel settlement in 2016 served as a warning not to tamper with vehicle emission systems. Apparently not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Perfect Candidate’ Review: Paving the Way
description: Haifaa Al-Mansour crafts a story that’s part family drama and part parable of female activism, set in Saudi Arabia.
content: Women in Saudi Arabia were granted the right to drive in 2018. In “The Perfect Candidate,” a film made in 2019 that is only now being released here, Maryam (Mila Al Zahrani), a physician in a small town, is seen driving purposefully to destinations that include an airport. At that airport, she is refused permission to board a plane because her travel permit has expired. Said permit needs the approval of a guardian for renewal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iyad Abuheweila and Vivian Yee
title: In Gaza, an Ordinary Street, and Extraordinary Horror, as Missiles Thunder In
description: A barber, a laundry worker and a family seeking safety were all caught up in the bloodshed of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
content: GAZA CITY — The taxi was loaded with everything the family would need for Eid al-Fitr, a holiday of feasts and cookies and new clothes that Israeli airstrikes on Gaza have transfigured this year into a time of swooping drones and fear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Extraterrestrial Plutonium Atoms Turn Up on Ocean Bottom
description: The rare form of the element found on the Pacific seabed points to its violent birth in colliding stars.
content: Scientists studying a sample of oceanic crust retrieved from the Pacific seabed nearly a mile down have discovered traces of a rare isotope of plutonium, the deadly element that has been central to the atomic age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Inside the Republican Anti-Transgender Machine
description: A.C.L.U. attorney Chase Strangio on the coordinated strategy behind the more than 100 anti-transgender bills introduced this year.
content: Republican lawmakers are suddenly obsessed with “saving women’s sports.” They’ve introduced over 100 bills in more than 30 states limiting trans children’s access to sports teams and gender-affirming health care. It’s a push to make trans issues the latest chapter in what is being framed as the culture wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: W.N.B.A. Preview: Don’t Bet Against the Aces in the West
description: The return of Liz Cambage and Kelsey Plum makes Las Vegas even more formidable. Did we mention it still has A’ja Wilson, the reigning M.V.P.?
content: The W.N.B.A. begins its 25th season on Friday with the returns of some big-name veterans and the debuts of promising rookies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman and Carl Zimmer
title: Another Group of Scientists Calls for Further Inquiry Into Origins of the Coronavirus
description: Researchers urge an open mind, saying lack of evidence leaves theories of natural spillover and laboratory leak both viable.
content: A group of 18 scientists stated Thursday in a letter published in the journal Science that there is not enough evidence to decide whether a natural origin or an accidental laboratory leak caused the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Los Hermanos/The Brothers’ Review: A Long-Deferred Duet
description: In this documentary, two musician siblings — one who lives in Cuba, the other in the United States — get a chance to tour together.
content: A moving documentary with generous amounts of music, “Los Hermanos/The Brothers” follows two musician siblings from Havana whose personal closeness is at odds with the geopolitics that keep them apart. Ilmar Gavilán, a violinist, left at 14 to study in Moscow and later immigrated to the United States. Aldo López-Gavilán, his younger brother, a pianist and composer, mostly stayed in Cuba, apart from conservatory training in London. Until December 2014, when President Obama announced a restoration of American relations with Cuba, the brothers — the sons of professional musicians — had few opportunities to perform together, or even to see each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar
title: Gaza’s Rockets: A Replenished Arsenal That Vexes Israel
description: Despite a blockade, Palestinian militants have used help from Iran, ingenuity, Israeli-fired duds and even plumbing pipes to make thousands of rockets with increased range.
content: CAIRO — They smuggle the parts or make their own, aided with know-how from Iran. They repurpose plumbing pipes scavenged from abandoned Israeli settlements and components culled from dud Israeli bombs. They assemble the rockets underground or in dense neighborhoods that the Israelis are reluctant to strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘The Stonewall You Know Is a Myth. And That’s O.K.’
description: What is the significance of the Stonewall uprising? Why are the events of that historic night still the subject of great debate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Chaos in the streets in Israel.
content: Hundreds of people have been arrested on rioting charges in Israel, and the city of Lod was placed on lockdown after groups of Jews and Arabs faced off violently in the streets. Several Israeli leaders, led by President Reuven Rivlin, evoked the specter of civil war — a once unthinkable idea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Spring Beauty Guide
description: Vitamin C serums, luminous blush — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. This week, to coincide with the publication of our Beauty & Luxury issue, T staffers and contributors highlight the products and trends they’re most excited about this spring. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Roller-Skate Backward
description: Once you can confidently go forward, it’s time to learn how to skate in reverse.
content: “Your mind gets twisted going backward, but your skates roll the same way in either direction,” says Ana Coto, 30, a Los Angeles-based actress and dancer who in the early days of the pandemic posted a TikTok video of herself blissfully roller-skating down a wide, empty street while singing along to Jennifer Lopez’s song “Jenny From the Block.” The video has been viewed more than 17 million times and has been credited with prompting what would become a Covid-19 roller-skating boom. Once you get over the mental confusion caused by rolling backward, rear-facing skating is its own special kind of movement. “It’s more like dancing,” Coto says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘‘‘Belonging Is Stronger Than Facts”: The Age of Misinformation’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about how social and psychological factors contribute to the spread of misinformation.
content: Featured Article: “‘Belonging Is Stronger Than Facts’: The Age of Misinformation” by Max Fisher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: En Route to the Best-Seller List, Oprah Was His Co-Pilot
description: Bruce D. Perry talks about what it’s like to write a book with a co-author who needs no introduction.
content: SUPER SOUL What’s it like to write a book with Oprah Winfrey? Is she the kind of collaborator we all remember from group projects in high school — the deadbeat who goes dark until the bulk of the work is completed? Or is the queen of incisive interviews (and basically everything) a latter-day Tracy Flick, getting it all done herself without input from anyone else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Emily Cochrane
title: White House Is Said to Quietly Push Change to D.C. Statehood Bill
description: The deliberations over the long-shot bill center on three Electoral College votes the Constitution gives to the seat of government.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has quietly approached congressional Democrats about a potential change to their high-profile but long-shot effort to transform most of the District of Columbia into the nation’s 51st state, according to executive and legislative branch officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A City Under Siege: What the War Looks Like on Afghanistan’s Front Line
description: As bullets from a Taliban machine gun ricocheted through the street below, an Afghan soldier wearing an “I Heart Kabul” T-shirt took a brief rest. “There has been fighting day and night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Deaths of Mail-Order Pets in Mystery Boxes Set Off a Backlash in China
description: Puppies and kittens shipped in packages across the country have ended up dead, distressed or infected, spurring outrage.
content: HONG KONG — The mystery pet boxes are listed on e-commerce platforms in China as a bargain, priced at little more than a few dollars, and they often contain cuddly animals ready to be mailed straight to your doorstep.
source.name: The New York Times

title: W.N.B.A. Preview: The Mystics Get Their Stars Back in the East
description: Also: Much has changed for the Atlanta Dream since last season, and Candace Parker brings championship hopes to the Chicago Sky.
content: The W.N.B.A. begins its 25th season on Friday with the returns of some big-name veterans and the debuts of promising rookies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: That ‘Ziwe’ Look
description: On her new Showtime series, Ziwe Fumudoh’s feminine-with-a-wink style enables her sharp comedy.
content: In the first episode of her new variety series on Showtime, the comedian Ziwe Fumudoh asks the writer Fran Lebowitz: “What bothers you more: slow walkers or racism?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How Klobuchar and Hawley See Things When It Comes to Technology
description: The senators are on opposite sides of the aisle, but both speak out on the dangers of big tech in their new books. It’s weird, really, how alike they sound.
content: Would you like to read a U.S. senator’s book about antitrust law? No? How about two U.S. senators’ books about antitrust law?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Gateses’ Public Split Spotlights a Secretive Fortune
description: Their marital estate is enormous and complex, containing assets as varied as stocks and farmland. Divvying it up could have implications for philanthropy.
content: The fortune of Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates exceeds the size of Morocco’s annual economy, combines the value of Ford, Twitter and Marriott International and is triple the endowment of Harvard. While few know how their wealth will be divided in the divorce, one thing is clear: breaking it up can’t be easy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Middle-Class Pay Lost Pace. Is Washington to Blame?
description: A new paper by liberal economists presents evidence that policymakers helped hold down wages for four decades.
content: One of the most urgent questions in economics is why pay for middle-income workers has increased only slightly since the 1970s, even as pay for those near the top has escalated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boeing Says F.A.A. Has Approved New Fix for 737 Max
description: The troubled jet resumed flying commercially in the United States late last year. But Boeing asked airlines last month to stop flying some of the planes because of a potential electrical problem.
content: Boeing says it has received approval from U.S. aviation authorities for proposed fixes to an electrical problem that grounded a portion of its troubled 737 Max fleet for more than a month. The approval is welcome news for the handful of affected airlines in the United States, where the industry is preparing for a busy summer.

title: This Is How Wokeness Ends
description: The meritocracy beats the radicals.
content: My friend Rod Dreher recently had a blog post for The American Conservative called “Why Are Conservatives in Despair?” He explained that conservatives are in despair because a hostile ideology — wokeness or social justice or critical race theory — is sweeping across America the way Bolshevism swept across the Russian Empire before the October Revolution in 1917.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Those Who Wish Me Dead’ Review: A Desperate Scramble to Survive
description: This thriller starring Angelina Jolie takes its time but doesn’t waste any time.
content: I’m not sure I believed the plot for a minute of “Those Who Wish Me Dead,” but as a means of pitting righteous characters against implacable assassins in a succession of abrupt, pitiless, life-or-death confrontations, the story has a terse effectiveness. The film, based on the 2014 novel by Michael Koryta, has been brought to the screen by the writer-director Taylor Sheridan. Although he isn’t the sole screenwriter here, the film paints in the bold, primal strokes of his scripts for “Sicario” and “Hell or High Water” without getting bogged down in the sloggy self-seriousness of his previous directorial feature, “Wind River.”
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Candidates divided on ‘defund the police’ issue as shooting and homicides rise in New York City.
description: Andrew Yang and Eric Adams, the two leading candidates roundly rejected the strategy. Maya Wiley said she would redirect some of the money destined for police to alternative strategies.
content: The idea of “defunding” the police, which a year ago became a rallying cry after the murder of George Floyd, proved to be a contentious proposition during the debate, dividing the candidates along ideological lines, particularly as New York City reels from an uptick in crime.
source.name: The New York Times

title: My Child Asks, ‘Can Israel Destroy Our Building if the Power Is Out?’
description: Being a good parent in Gaza means developing a knack for what Israel’s drones and F-16’s will do next.
content: TAL AL-HAWA, Gaza Strip — On Tuesday night, my wife, six children and I huddled in the living room of our apartment, the place least likely to take a stray hit from Israeli missiles or the debris they scatter. We were watching Al Jazeera’s livestreaming of Israeli warplanes’ imminent destruction of al-Jawharah (The Gem), one of Gaza’s largest buildings, when the power went out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The People in the Neighborhood
description: A powerful — and revealing — aspect of the Derek Chauvin trial was the community it created out of strangers.
content: Weeks later, we’re still thinking about the witnesses in the trial of Derek Chauvin, and the way they were connected in telling the story of how George Floyd lost his life. This phenomenon is reflected in works of art, like Spike Lee’s “Do the Right Thing,” which explores the conflict inherent in a community.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: St. Vincent Flirts With Autobiography and the Sounds of the ’70s
description: On her sixth solo album, “Daddy’s Home,” the singer and songwriter Annie Clark turns her world-building and role-playing briefly inward.
content: In the middle of St. Vincent’s last album, the sleek and slinky “Masseduction” from 2017, there is an uncharacteristically sparse piano ballad called “Happy Birthday, Johnny.” Unlike a lot of St. Vincent songs, this one is almost provocatively simple: just a lovely melody that Annie Clark’s voice imbues with warm, weary pathos.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Black Student Athlete Was Forced to Remove Hair Beads During Game
description: Nicole Pyles, 16, of Durham, N.C., says that a rule banning the use of hair beads by student athletes is discriminatory.
content: A North Carolina high school softball player says she wants to end rules that discriminate against Black student athletes after being forced to cut her hair beads during a game last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Brazilian
title: Love Artisanal Soaps? Make Your Own
description: Susan Ryhanen, who creates Saipua’s specialty bars with her daughter at their farm in upstate New York, offers a step-by-step guide on how to reproduce their sudsy magic.
content: Who would have thought that good old-fashioned soap would, more than four millenniums after its invention, still be one of humankind’s most powerful tools in fighting disease? Over the past year or so, we have been reminded of this fact, and of the simple magic of hand washing, with its unequaled germ-killing (and lifesaving) powers. Which means that possessing a truly fantastic bar — sudsy, fragrant and mood elevating — is more sensible than ever. But to understand what makes a great soap, one must go back in time. There are several origin stories (most set in ancient Babylon), all of which involve the accidental (and perhaps barbecue-related) discovery that pairing wood ash with animal fat drippings (scientifically speaking: sodium or potassium hydroxide and a triglyceride) led to the miraculous chemical reaction we now call saponification, which results in a highly effective grime-removing solid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Experts Urge Strict Workplace Air Quality Standards, in Wake of Pandemic
description: The researchers issued a call to action to improve indoor air quality as a safeguard against the spread of contagions like the coronavirus.
content: Clean water in 1842, food safety in 1906, a ban on lead-based paint in 1971. These sweeping public health reforms transformed not just our environment but expectations for what governments can do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: When Does the Curtain Rise on Your Favorite Broadway Shows?
description: Here are the plans for 23 productions so far, including old favorites, brand-new musicals and some that were just getting started.
content: After being closed for more than a year, Broadway is showing signs of life. Several long-running musicals, including “The Lion King” and “Wicked,” have recently announced when they will reopen this fall. Shows that were just beginning their runs, and had not yet opened, when the pandemic struck — like “Six,” “Diana” and “Mrs. Doubtfire” — have also released their plans for resuming performances. The revival of “Caroline, or Change” and the new Michael Jackson biomusical “MJ” have taken their first steps toward welcoming audiences, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Stanford Faces Two Lawsuits for Decision to Cut Sports
description: The suits are a last-ditch effort by some athletes, alumni and supporters to save 11 sports planned to be cut after this school year.
content: Athletes at Stanford filed a pair of lawsuits against the university on Wednesday in a last-ditch effort to force it to reinstate most of the 11 sports it is axing at the end of the current school year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Broadway Plans Its Return, ‘Hamilton’ Will Require Vaccines Backstage

title: Chip Roy challenges Elise Stefanik to replace Liz Cheney in House G.O.P. leadership.
description: Republicans are scheduled to meet Friday morning to select Ms. Cheney’s replacement as chair of the House Republican Conference.
content: Representative Chip Roy of Texas, a strident conservative, will run against Representative Elise Stefanik of New York for the No. 3 House Republican leadership position, a move of protest reflecting unhappiness among hard-right lawmakers with the congresswoman party leaders anointed to replace Representative Liz Cheney.

title: 2 Climbers Die on Everest as Pandemic Rampages Through Nepal

content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Two climbers, a Swiss-Pakistani and an American, have died on Mount Everest, the first fatalities of a busy climbing season as a second wave of the coronavirus batters Nepal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Showing Little Contrition, David Cameron Faces U.K. Parliament in Lobbying Scandal

content: Politics provide a through line for some of this week’s recommended books, from the focused activism of the early AIDS era (in Sarah Schulman’s “Let the Record Show”) to the history of government efforts to fight monopoly power (in Senator Amy Klobuchar’s “Antitrust”) to the plot of Richard Wright’s resurrected novel “The Man Who Lived Underground,” in which the Black protagonist is wrongly accused of murder.

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Many Unvaccinated Latinos in the U.S. Want the Shot, New Survey Finds
description: Issues of access and fears of employment and immigration consequences have kept their Covid vaccination rates low, the findings suggest.
content: Latino adults in the United States have the lowest rates of Covid-19 vaccination, but among the unvaccinated they are the demographic group most willing to receive the Covid shots as soon as possible, a new survey shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Inflation Is Here. What Now?
description: Prices are rising fast, in ways that seem temporary, yet this could change expectations in ways that are self-reinforcing.
content: The central fact of the American economy in mid-2021 is that demand for all sorts of goods and services has surged. But supplies are coming back slowly, with the economy acting like a creaky machine that was turned off for a year and has some rusty parts.

title: As Trillions Flow Out the Door, Stimulus Oversight Faces Challenges

content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers have unleashed more than $5 trillion in relief aid over the past year to help businesses and individuals through the pandemic downturn. But the scale of that effort is placing serious strain on a patchwork oversight network created to ferret out waste and fraud.

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Spiral: From the Book of Saw’ Review: Slicing Up Bad Apples
description: This addition to the “Saw” universe stars Chris Rock as a misanthropic detective pitted against a Jigsaw copycat.
content: In “Spiral,” the latest film in the “Saw” universe, the first expletives land before the two-minute mark. Blood spills right after, when a man has to decide between getting his tongue ripped out or being hit by an underground train. That the film is overall gorier and more foulmouthed than its predecessors, while still managing an R rating, is undoubtedly an accomplishment. Unfortunately, that is the film’s only notable one.

title: Baseball in Britain Confronts Issues With Sexism
description: A sexist tweet, and a refusal to delete it, prompted the general manager of the British women’s national team to resign in protest. The sport wants her back.
content: It is no exaggeration to say that Amanda Hocking has dedicated her life to baseball — especially women’s baseball — in Britain. Playing the game has been her dream since she was a child.

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Riders of Justice’ Review: Just Give Me a Reason
description: Mads Mikkelsen goes berserk in this gleefully violent, yet gold-hearted deconstruction of the revenge thriller.
content: In the jarring opening scene of “Riders of Justice,” one girl’s bike is stolen and turned into another kid’s Christmas present, kicking off a chain of events that results in a disastrous subway explosion. When Otto (Nikolaj Lie Kaas), a probability expert suffering from a bad case of survivor’s guilt, pins the calamity on the leader of a criminal gang, he inadvertently triggers another round of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Elon Musk Makes a Hard Swerve on Bitcoin
description: In a sudden U-turn, Tesla stopped accepting the cryptocurrency as payment. But why?
content: Elon Musk has been a big cryptocurrency booster of late, even directing Tesla to buy $1.5 billion in Bitcoin for its corporate treasury earlier this year. Yesterday, he abruptly reversed course, tweeting that Tesla would stop accepting Bitcoin as payment for cars, citing environmental reasons. “We are concerned about rapidly increasing use of fossil fuels for Bitcoin mining and transactions, especially coal, which has the worst emissions of any fuel,” he said.

description: As the poet and writer Kima Jones prepared for Eid al-Fitr, she used it as a time to connect to herself, her ancestors and her family through food.
content: I was 13 the first time I fasted for Ramadan. That was 25 years ago, and each year has brought unique challenges and epiphanies. There were the years when I greeted Ramadan with spiritual goals, and the years when I felt sheer panic because I didn’t feel ready.

title: ‘I Feel Like I’m Just Drowning’: Sophomore Year in a Pandemic
description: A group of high school students try desperately to make it through an isolated and dire year.
content: On Aug. 11, Sarah, a cheerleader at Hickman High School in Columbia, Mo., turned 16 and passed her driving test. Triumphant, she arrived home to a Happy Birthday sign in the front yard, a treat of beignets from a Creole restaurant and the news that her 17-year-old brother did not have pinkeye, as their mother initially suspected, but Covid-19. They all did, it turned out: Sarah, who asked to be identified by her middle name to protect her privacy; her brother; their 85-year-old grandfather; and their mother, a nurse practitioner who started having trouble breathing two days after her son tested positive. Sarah had thought she would first take advantage of her license to drive herself to cheerleading practice; instead, she used it to take her mother to get a coronavirus test, when her mother realized she was already too weak to drive herself. Then, a week later, Sarah’s mother — who had not been leaving the couch and was having trouble finishing her sentences — told her she needed to be driven to the hospital. Her pastor and other members of her church would be checking in, but Sarah would have to look after everyone. That meant taking care of her grandfather, who had Parkinson’s disease and some dementia, and her brother, who had autism. Could she do that? Sarah, whose eyes had grown wide, quickly recovered. Yes, she told her mother. Of course she could.
